Yes, it's in the Volta Region of Ghana West Africa...come visit us...it's just about some 20km drive away from Ho, the Capital of Volta. Come let's have a view of all the Adaklu communities at the top of this wonderful mountain.

Hi, I'm wondering piece is. I commute on the train from its Addogonno station to either Circle, Odawna or the train stop at Accra.
Months ago, the train wasn't so congested. My guess is with the onset of the rains and damaged roads as a result more people have discovered this alternative and rather than go through Teshie or the bumpy 'Bush Road' everyone makes their way to various train stops. The increase in patrons of the train has thus increased sharply, so much that it is completely full when it leaves Addogonno. People have to stand the rest of the way to Achimota and Circle. A lot of passenger get of at Circle, its at that time that seats are available for everyone. The congestion makes purchasing and checking of tickets a big problem. Also when one has to get off at an earlier stop, he has to shove his way out in order to get off before the train resumes after its brief stop. The only place likely to be spared of the experience is the 1st class coach, which is only one. There have been times when coaches that ply the Asaprochona-Accra route have been donated allegedly to add to the number of coaches that arrive from Nsawam. Around these times its a scuffle to get onto the train, congestion occurs as well as other already mentioned problems.

Just thought. I'd let you know :)

I wonder how many rindeag this have a similar anecdotal opinion as I do: since getting right with my 25(OH)D blood level some 3 or 4 years ago, I have been able to tolerate even 8 hours of Texas Summer Sun with no sunscreen and no burning.  Of course, D helps, but is not a total armor against sunburn.  But every year of my life in memory, I would burn painfully once, in the springtime, and then tan darkly for the rest of the summer.  With > 50ng/ml I have been absent that yearly burn, even if I spend 6 days in a row inside working, never seeing the sun high in the sky, and then go spend that Sunday on the roof working without a shirt and of course, no sunscreen.  I wonder how many others have this benefit but don't realize it?

portato a costituire un'associazione per la tutela degli investitori italiani in egitto,ha coinvolto l'Ambasciata italiana del Cairo,e con l'appoggio di un Ministro e del TDA egiziano ha fatto pressione sul costrutture il quale l'ha ricevuto, e dopo una serie di incontri hanno trovato un accordo .Sapete una cosa,oggi mi ha mandata una  e -mail dicendomi che si dispiaceva di non poter essere presente alla riunione,perche8 lui il 6 ottobre ha un volo(da Bologna) per marsa alam per ritirare le chiavi del suo nuovo appartamento,inoltre mi comunicava che sarebbe andato anche alla polizia di marsa alam per fare denuncia contro el sery per il mabr e che al suo ritorno mi avrebbe aggiornato.Tanto di cappello Roberto,e augurissimi per la tua nuova casa.Per quanto riguarda la nostra riunione vi comunico che per il momento c'e8 una discreta adesione,quello che vorrei trasmettervi e8 l'importanza di unirci e vederci,discutere insieme.L'incontro con lo studio legale deve essere un motivo per incontrarci,se non va bene l'avvocato ( e8 comprensibile perche8 ognuno di noi ha gie0 subito un grosso danno economico),ma comunque credo che insieme potremmo fare cose che nemmeno immaginiamo.Aveto visto Roberto da solo cosa ha fatto.Gli inglesi stanno facendo un grande lavoro.Oggi mi ha telefonato l'avvocato che ha fatto la relazione,mi diceva che gli e8 arrivata un-email di uno studio legale del Cairo,credo che sia lo studio interpellato dagli inglesi perche8 parlano di collaborazione,o magari sare0 un'altro studio,non lo sf2,non mi interessa al momento (poi magari vi giro l'email).La cosa importante adesso e8 incontrarci,mettere da parte la rabbia che abbiamo tutti,e inziare a pensare alle varie soluzioni.Qualcuno mi ha scritto che per venire alla riunione deve fare 200 km sono tanti,io ho risposto che sotto casa sua non la possiamo fare.Tutte le persone che verranno faranno un piccolo sacrificio,vengono persone dalla Sicilia,da Napoli ecc. ognuno fe0 la sua parte.Non abbiamo tanto tempo per la conferma della partecipazione,perche8 dopo dobbiamo organizzarci per la sede e altri dettagli.Quindi vi invito a chi e8 interessato di mandare la conferma entro i prossimi 2 Hi Lawrence, thanks for conitctang Plugin Dynamo support. I'll answer your questions numbered as you asked them:1. Yes, only images that are using in your post are uploaded to your server. The process Buzz goes through to capture images is, it scans the feed items looks for all image url's once it has them it associates each image with the post data for the feed, if more feeds are found than you want in your post, it randomly filters them and once it has the final ones to use in the post, it goes through and add it to the post and saves the image locally.2.In the settings page I believe there's a setting for max image height and max image width, this is for the imported images.3. They will still work, but images won't show up and in some browsers people will see the image wont load box i.e. chrome I believe does this.4. You use to be able to do this, but it caused alot of confusion, so now its for the whole campaign as you said it all or nothing.If there's anything else you would like to know just let us know.Thanks,Plugin Dynamo Support

Hi John, thanks for cotticnang Plugin Dynamo Support.Unfortunately there is no way to increase/decrease the check email time limit. It is set to every 15 minutes though and fires off through a WordPress cron job. But your hick up might be coming from the fact that WordPress cron jobs don't work exactly like a regular server cron job. Every time an action happens on your site, someone lands on any page, you log in as admin, you browse admin pages your WordPress install fires off the cron, and scans through at what job's are set to run at that time, if no jobs are set to run, nothing happens. If there are jobs it runs them.So that's why there's a little bit of give and take on the time. No action on the site = cron doesn't fire to retrieve emails.You can however manually retrieve the emails by visiting settings > email settings this will force a check.Or you can edit the time limit yourself in the code, by editing line #427 Currently:  interval' => 900, to a desired time you want (in seconds) 900/60 = 15 minutes.5 minutes would be 300If you change it this way, de-activate the Plugin and re-activate it and the new schedule time should be in the cron job for you. Just be sure to go back and re-edit the line should you ever update the Plugin.Thanks,Plugin Dynamo Support

Great article, that cofirnms my intuitions about the lack of efficiency of sliders, regarding user engagement. I also consider it a sign of a difficulty to make content priorities choices, which should ring a bell about the decision process in the project.On the accessibility front, an additional problem is that, too often, keyboard users are neglected. Sliders are not standard elements of HTML, so sliders designers have to cope with existing HTML, CSS and javascript code, creatively combining them to simulate this slideshow effect. Unfortunately, not all of them consider alternative uses, such as tabbing through the slides via the Tab key. Depending on the way it's done, sometimes you can't get focus on any element; and other times you do get focus, but on elements inside a given slide, like anchor links, and that can break the display in some situations, making it unusable.Another common issue is not having an adequate fallback when javascript is not supported. Whereas it's pretty simple to achieve, as long as the slider has been built on appropriate HTML, that for instance shows all the slides as a list, by default.

Kinny from U.S.A., September 24, 2012 at 6:21 PM                                       Resort Frati is nestled in a dirtamac and historic hillside. Its hosts-a husband and wife duo welcomed us into their home and history with open arms. Upon checking in we were showered with ideas for places to eat, to visit and to experience. We were escorted to a country house where we experienced the most glorious local fare. We would have never found this place without a personal escort or suggestions from our hosts. Our host Cheserina made reservations for us to eat at another restaurant in Borghetto where they served homemade tortellini! The rooms in the Resort are beautiful beyond measure, loving restored and built to the finest detail. The stone walls, large wooden beams, meticulously tiled floors and bathrooms are a dream. When you enter the rooms you feel like you are truly living in Northern Italy. The indoor pool is elegant and inviting and the hosts are always on hand to offer a refreshment or glass of procecco to enjoy as you watch the sunset from the large windows in the pool area or on the front patio. The breakfast is substantial, with scrambled eggs, meats, breads, cheeses and pastries. The coffee is exquisite too but that is to be expected-you are in Italy!! I just can't say enough about the service and the beauty of this place. I only wish we could have stayed longer than four nights. This is definitely on my top 10 to do again!

I loved this as a kid, but I've been twice disappointed when I bhguot it for my own children.  Just like others, we have gotten the sludge at the bottom of the tank.  However, I have a few suggestions that might help. (1) Mix the solution really well.  The gel that they provide is so heavy that it sinks to the bottom of the tank and promotes growth spreading out along the bottom, rather than up. (2) Use 1/3 of the rocks to make the bedrock for the second batch.  We did get the sludge with these rocks, but it is true that the second batch needs to be placed on this bedrock rather than on a sludge-free place in the tank. (3)Our most useful discovery was when we suspected the rocks are old and oxidized.  I scraped the surfaces of each rock with a nail file to expose new material. (4) I haven't completely solved the problem of the rocks growing up and spreading out across the surface of the water, but I suspect that scraping all of the surfaces will promote multiple slender columns rather than one chimney that reaches the water's surface and then spreads out. (5) Because the rock scraping is time consuming and I am still experimenting with the product, I have not yet poured out the old solution and replaced it with fresh water.  If I had been more on top of that (growing them in a day rather than over the course of a week), I might have been able to preserve the intense colors of the rocks. I hope these suggestions help, or at least spur new thinking on how to make these rocks grow beautifully like they did in the  good old days!'

Thanks for your comments and aaylws-insightful perspective. Market entry costs depend on the market geographic size, the market niche size, the mode of entry, the types of marketing promotion needed, country-specific setup costs and the mode of product/service delivery. Most entrepreneurs I talk to and work with typically choose to start off small in their internationalization. They find a good local partner who can represent their products in-country in exchange for either representation in our country or else a steep commission fee per item sold. This entry mode is the least cost and least risk. Many would argue that it is the least reward too. Typically the evolution I've seen when I company realizes that they can compete profitably in a market is to move from partners/representatives/licensees to eventually setting up a local sales office. If a partnership proves to be highly fruitful in more than just sales, then it may be advantageous to eventually either set up a joint venture entity, try to acquire the partner or set up a greenfield investment in-country on your own. There are lots of options with different price tags. The range can easily be from US$10,000 to US$10 million. If any entrepreneurial companies need weighing entry options and budgeting for international markets, this is a major part of what my company does for small and medium-sized companies.

fields.name: Elmina Bay resort
fields.caption:
Elmina Bay is a brand new hotel in the Cape Coast/Elmina area in the heart of the historic Central Region of Ghana. The resort, about 10 minutes drive from Elmina and 25 minutes from Cape Coast, is located on a beautiful, clean, palm-fringed beach, with cool and clean sea water, great for bathing.
Address: PO Box EL 325, Elmina, Ghana, West Africa

Email: elminabayresort@gmail.com

Phone: 054 161 4812 / 020 566 0670 / 028 524 0202 
Use country code 00233 from outside Ghana

fields.name: Bus
fields.caption: Travel to Mole National Park is done via Tamale by bus, taxi or rental car. You can also book a safari to Mole National Park from a Ghanaian tour operator. There is no public transport within the Park but there are some taxis available in nearby Larabanga. Car rental is not available in Mole but you can reach the park by renting a car in Ghana. Walking in the park is forbidden without an armed ranger for safety reasons.

fields.name: Citi FM
fields.caption:
Citi 97.3 FM is a private radio station in Accra-Ghana. 
The station has a reach of about 90km radius, with a dominant presence in Greater Accra, Eastern, Central and parts of Volta and Western Regions.
Citi 97.3FM presents all its programmes in English language and has a mix of adult contemporary music, news and current affairs programmes.

www.citifmonline.com

fields.name: Museum
fields.caption: A small museum is situated in the farm yard for visitors to see some items Tetteh Quarshie used in his time

fields.name: Aburi Gardens
fields.caption: This century - old botanical gardens, is about an hours drive from Accra and offers a rich collection of tropical flora, which attracts scores of birds and butterflies.

fields.name: Aburi Gardens
fields.caption: The Gardens were originally created in 1890 as an agricultural research station and a habitat for plants from around the world.

fields.name: Aburi Gardens
fields.caption: Plans have been drawn for major renovations to bring it back up to its original international standard for visitors and tourists.

fields.name: Aburi Gardens
fields.caption: Arauraria Cunninghamii(Araucaraceae) This tree was planted by the Ex-President J.J Rawlings on the occassion of the Aburi Odwira festival on the 19th October,1990.

fields.name: Aburi Gardens
fields.caption: The Travellers Palm - The majestic fan-shaped silhouette of this loving plant (Ravenala Madagas Cariensis) has stimulated wide plantings in tropical gardens. Thirsty travellers have been known to drink water trapped at the base of the leaves hence the name Travellers Tree

fields.name: Aburi Gardens
fields.caption: Cieba Pentandra(Silk Cotton tree) This tree was planted on 25th May 1924 by Sir Gordon Guggisberg, governor of the Goldcoast. One of the largest trees in West Africa, up to 160ft, or more 6ft or more in diameter, girth up to 25ft above buttress. It is one of the sacred trees of West Africa

fields.name: Cocoa
fields.caption: Cocoa - The seed of this South American tree (Theobroma Cacao) have been used for food since ancient times, the Aztecs of Central America called it food for the gods, believing it was of devine origin. This is also reflected in its scientific name, Theos = gods, broma = food. In Aztec community only those of importance were allowed to drink the bitter beverage made form pounded roasted cacao beans, maize and chilli pepper. Today major cocoa producers include Brazil, Ghana and Ivory Coast

fields.name: Shea Butter
fields.caption: Shea butter tree - origin: Guinea Savannah of Africa. It is called after Mungo Park. The fruit-pulp is sweet and commonly eaten unprocessed by both humans and animals. the kernels are rich in oil (45 - 55%) by weight) known as shea butter which is extracted after pounding and grinding into paste the roasted kernels. The shea butter is used extensively as vegetable oil in cooking, soap and candle making and in cosmetics.

fields.name: Aburi Gardens (Tree lined)
fields.caption: Its tranquil tree lined walkways are popular leisure grounds for our city dwellers.

fields.name: Elmina Bay resort
fields.caption:
Elmina Bay is a brand new hotel in the Cape Coast/Elmina area in the heart of the historic Central Region of Ghana. The resort, about 10 minutes drive from Elmina and 25 minutes from Cape Coast, is located on a beautiful, clean, palm-fringed beach, with cool and clean sea water, great for bathing.
Address: PO Box EL 325, Elmina, Ghana, West Africa

Email: elminabayresort@gmail.com

Phone: 054 161 4812 / 020 566 0670 / 028 524 0202 
Use country code 00233 from outside Ghana

fields.caption: One of the best strikers the world has ever seen, Tony Yeboah, owns the Yegoala hotel in Asore Danho at Dansoman - Accra. Yegoala also has a nite club and it's well known for it's pool parties.

fields.name: SWOPA home
fields.caption: The village is well known for its traditional architecture, pottery and wall designing. Since 1997, more than 150 women of Sirigu have formed an organization for pottery and art (SWOPA: Sirigu women organisation of pottery and art).

fields.name: SWOPA home in Sirigu
fields.caption: Their aim is to preserve and develop their traditional culture and to provide tourist services and produce high quality art that has its roots in the village culture.

fields.name: Sirigu Baskets
fields.caption: High quality pottery, baskets and paintings are for sale for moderate prices. Learn the history of the pottery, and the symbolism of the patterns used in the art and wall decoration. You may be able to talk with the artists themselves.

fields.name: Wardances
fields.caption: Wardances: a different rhythm is used during the historic wardance. For this occasion men are dressed in a traditional smock with a colourful cap and holding bows and arrows with quivers as a symbol of bravery.

fields.name: Sirigu Pots
fields.caption: High quality pottery, baskets and paintings are for sale for moderate prices. Learn the history of the pottery, and the symbolism of the patterns used in the art and wall decoration. You may be able to talk with the artists themselves.

fields.name: Sirigu Art
fields.caption: You can arrange in advance to work with the SWOPA artists and learn the techniques involved in pottery, baskets, and even wall designs. SWOPA members will take you through the entire process.

fields.name: War dances
fields.caption: Wardances: a different rhythm is used during the historic wardance. For this occasion men are dressed in a traditional smock with a colourful cap and holding bows and arrows with quivers as a symbol of bravery.

fields.name: SWOPA home
fields.caption: Experience the silence of the night, the moon and stars unaffected by artifical lights, and listen to the wakening calls of the birds and the women fetching water.

fields.name: SWOPA home
fields.caption: Former UN secretary general Kofi Annan visited the SWOPA home on August 19, 2002

fields.name: Volta Lake
fields.caption: The Volta Lake is one of the largest man-made lakes in the world. Created in 1965 as a result of the damming of the Volta River at Akosombo.

fields.name: Cruise Boat
fields.caption: The Lake offers a variety of opportunities for cruises, water sports and angling. It also has many fascinating Islands and islets such as Dodi Island

fields.name: Polo Game
fields.caption: Polo must be played right-handed. Left-handed play was ruled out in 1975 for safety reasons. To date, only 3 players on the world circuit are left-handed.

fields.name: Polo Game
fields.caption: There are tall collapsable goalposts at each end of the field spread 8 yards apart. The object of the game is to score the most goals by hitting the ball through the goal. Ends are changed after a goal is scored.

fields.name: W.E.B Du Bios
fields.caption: William Edward Burghardt Du Bois(February 23, 1868 â€“ August 27, 1963) was an American civil rights activist, Pan-Africanist, sociologist, historian, author, and editor. At the age of 95, in 1963, he became a naturalized citizen of Ghana

fields.name: Tourist sites in Ghana : W.E.B Du Bois Memorial Centre
fields.caption: The W.E.B. Du Bois Memorial Centre is located in the Cantonments district of Accra, and visitors can see personal effects and photographs of Du Bois

fields.name: Tourist sites in Ghana : Aburi Botanical Gardens
fields.caption: This century - old botanical gardens, is about an hours drive from Accra and offers a rich collection of tropical flora, which attracts scores of birds and butterflies.

fields.name: Tourist sites in Ghana : Wli waterfalls
fields.caption: It is 20km from Hohoe, in the Wli Natural Reserve. This waterfall is becoming very popular in the West African sub-region.It is perennial, as water cascades throughout the year.The water drops from a height of about 1600 feet.

fields.name: Black Heritage Musuem
fields.caption: This Museum is in the home, library and final resting place of American-born crusader for social justice, William Edward Burghardt DuBois.

fields.name: Roots Flavours
fields.caption: This is a Bar and Restaurant in the Premises of the W.E.B Du Bios Centre and Ghanaian and Continental dishes are served together with chilled drinks anytime

fields.name: W.E.B Du Bios
fields.caption: The W.E.B. Du Bois Memorial Centre is located in the Cantonments district of Accra, and visitors can see personal effects and photographs of Du Bois

fields.name: W.E.B Du Bios
fields.caption: The W.E.B. Du Bois Memorial Centre is located in the Cantonments district of Accra, and visitors can see personal effects and photographs of Du Bois

fields.name: Diaspora African Forum Mission
fields.caption: Diaspora African Forum Mission, this office can also be found in the W.E.B Du Bios premises

fields.name: W.E.B Du Bios and Kwame Nkrumah
fields.caption: Du Bois was invited to Ghana in 1961 by President Kwame Nkrumah to direct the Encyclopedia Africana, a government production, and a long-held dream of his. When, in 1963, he was refused a new U.S. passport, he and his wife, Shirley Graham Du Bois, became citizens of Ghana.

fields.name: W.E.B Du Bois
fields.caption: One of the early 20th Century's most noted Black Scholars W.E.B Du Bois

fields.name: Tourist sites in Ghana : Paga Crocodile pond
fields.caption: Paga is noted for it's sacred pond, which is a sanctuary for crocodiles. The crocodiles are said to be totems for the people of Kassena, who reside in Paga and the surrounding communities.

fields.name: Tourist sites in Ghana : Ada Foah
fields.caption: Accra Tema Yacht Club (ATYC) is loacted in Ada, at the mouth of the River Volta, some 112km by road from Accra. However, most of their members live in Accra and there is an active social scene revolving around Ryans Irish Pub, Osu, which is now their Accra Home

fields.name: Tourist sites in Ghana : Dodi Princess
fields.caption: Journey on the Volta Lake from Akosombo Harbour to Dodi Island.6 hours on the boat There is a nice high live band. You can dance, eat drink, tan the whole day, or watch the river sides.

fields.name: Tourist sites in Ghana : Kakum National Park
fields.caption: Kakum National Park is in the southern part of Ghana, it is the best preserved region of virgin rainforest in the country and provides the easiest access to the rainforest for tourists along with the famous canopy walkway. The easiest starting point for a trip to Kakum is Cape Coast, the regional capital. Tro-tro's run regularly to Kakum and beyond, alternatively you can charter a taxi.the park is approximately a 1 hour journey from Cape Coast.

fields.name: Tourist sites in Ghana : Proverbial Coffins in Accra
fields.caption: In Ghana, carving of coffins in various styles started in 1977,when a carpenter named Ataa Owuo lost his Grandmother and carved a coffin in the shape of an aeroplane.

fields.name: Tourist sites in Ghana : Nzulezu
fields.caption: The famous village on stilts is located 90km west of Takoradi about an hour's drive from the beautiful beaches of Busua.

fields.name: Tourist sites in Ghana : Cape Coast Castle
fields.caption: Cape Coast grew around Cape Coast Castle, now a World Heritage Site. It was converted to a castle by the Dutch in 1637, then expanded by the Swedes in 1652 and captured by the British in 1664.It is situated 165 km west of Accra on the Gulf of Guinea.

fields.name: Tourist sites in Ghana : Elmina Castle
fields.caption: Elmina Castle was erected by the Portuguese in 1482.It was the first trading post built on the Gulf of Guinea, so is the oldest European building in existence below the Sahara.It is situated 165 km west of Accra on the Gulf of Guinea.

fields.name: Tourist sites in Ghana : Fort Prinzenstein
fields.caption: This Fort was among the four major Danish structures in Ghana, built in the commercial capital of the 36 Anlo towns, Keta in 1784 AD.

fields.name: Tourist sites in Ghana : Paragliding
fields.caption: The Paragliding Festival is held in March or April of 2008. This festival is hosted by the Ghanaian Ministry of Tourism at Kwahu in the Eastern region

fields.name: Tourist sites in Ghana : Independence Square
fields.caption: Ghana attained her independence from Britain on March 6, 1957, and has over the years marked the day with national celebrations. Which is always held here at the Independence Square.

fields.name: Tourist sites in Ghana : Kwame Nkrumah Mausoleum
fields.caption: Just along the coast from Independence Square lies the Kwame Nkrumah Memorial Park, a tasteful homage to Ghana's first President. Kwame Nkrumah is buried in this grand mausoleum in Accra.

fields.name: Light House
fields.caption: A lighthouse, the Jamesfort Light, was built by the British at James Fort in 1871. Jamestown is now a fishing port populated primarily by the Ga, an indigenous people of coastal Ghana. It is also a tourist destination for those wishing to see the remnants of Accra's colonial past. The original lighthouse was replaced in the 1930s by the current Accra Light, which is 93 ft (28 m) tall with a visibility of 16 nautical miles (30 km).

fields.name: James Town
fields.caption: This is the front door to the Jamestown Prison. Back during slavery days, the prison fort was used to house slaves and hold them in preparation to be shipped off to other countries. It was still being used to house inmates, but the prison has been evacuated and is now being renovated into a tourist attraction.

fields.name: Ussher Fort
fields.caption:
Fort Ussher (Fort Crevecoer), a former prison where Kwame Nkrumah was once held...
Dutch post built in 1642. Enlarged and named Fort Crevecoeur, in 1652. Temporarily in British hands, in 1782. Returned to the Dutch in 1785. Abandoned in 1816. Damaged by earthquake, in 1862. Transferred to British, rebuilt and renamed Ussher Fort, in 1868.

fields.name: Kente
fields.caption: Kente cloth, known locally as nwentoma, is a type of silk fabric made of interwoven cloth strips and is native to the country of Ghana, where it was first developed in the 12th century.In Ghana, kente is made by the Akan people (including the Asante, Fante and Nzema). Kente is also produced by Akan groups in Cote d'Ivoire.a colorful fabric of Ghanaian origin: often worn as a symbol of African-American pride.

fields.name: Repairs
fields.caption: We always carry equipment for basic repairs (such as repairing a puncture or adjusting brakes/gears). We also carry a first aid kit. fields.name: Health Tips
fields.caption: Cycling is a great form of exercise, and its fun. It can be enjoyed by people of all ages. Cycling can provide you with a lot of health benefits too. It improves your cardiovascular fitness so you'll have a lower risk of heart attack and stroke. Pedaling is low impact, so you can improve muscle tone without stressing your knee and ankle joints. It is also a great mode of transportation. You can save a lot of fuel, save the environment from getting polluted and you will have to pay no parking fees.

fields.name: Riding
fields.caption: Like any outdoor activity, cycling has dangers that the rider should be aware of. Probably the biggest danger comes from sharing the road with cars. Although cycling is an activity that can be very beneficial in contributing towards a healthy lifestyle, it is important to realize that much cycling takes place on public roads shared with other vehicles. Cyclists need to know the basic skills and principles in cycling on the road. Cycling can be daunting to the novice cyclist especially on busy roads. By following a few basic safety measures, you can make cycling safer, more enjoyable, and much less stressful for yourself.

fields.name: Bicycles

fields.name: Monkeys
fields.caption: The many species of monkey have varied relationships with humans. Some are kept as pets, others used as model organisms in laboratories or in space missions. They may be killed in monkey drives when they threatened agriculture, or serve as service animals for the disabled.In religion and culture, the monkey often represents quick-wittedness and mischief.

fields.name: Monkey
fields.caption: The Patas Monkey (Erythrocebus patas) is a ground-dwelling monkey distributed over West Africa

fields.name: Monkey
fields.caption: The Dormaa District Assembly has pledged its support for the development of the Duasidan area and its proposed wildlife sanctuary. Within its limited capacity, it has been focusing attention on the community by regularly maintaining the road through the village, constructed a bore hole, etc.

fields.name: Monkey
fields.caption: This monkey lives in groups of about twelve individuals. There is a loose matrilineal dominance rank. The group contains just one adult male for most of the year. During the breeding season, there are multi-male influxes into the group.

fields.name: Monkey
fields.caption: The spiritual belief attached to the monkey sacred grove by the people of Duasidan Community in Dorman District of the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana has given a special status to their monkey sanctuary.

fields.name: Monkey
fields.caption: There is no legal protection (legislative instrument), as such are faced with related erosion of traditional values, agricultural expansion, demographic changes and religious growth. The hitherto traditional belief and practice that acted as effective control in protection the sacred grove is now being overwhelmed by these changes.

fields.name: Funeral for the Monkeys
fields.caption: Due to this spiritual nature, economic role, health support of this monkeys. Burial and funerals are normally preformed for the death of any monkeys.In the same vein the birth and death of any community member, the monkeys are accordingly informed through the pouring of libation and other sacrifices.

fields.name: Monkey
fields.caption: A monkey carrying it's baby

fields.name: Access to the Monkey Sanctuary
fields.caption: Access to the sacred grove until UNDP GEF intervention in 2005 been a taboo and a restricted place, especially for women, the opinion leaders had to lift the Spiritual Embargo to allow in the commencement of the project as well as receive Tourists both (men and woman).

fields.name: Monkey
fields.caption: The eating and dancing of the monkeys towards the overseers (okomfo) house represents overall community health at a particular point in time. The continuous mid-night fighting among monkey may symbolize uncleanness among community members or an imminent out break of disease. It is among the collection of these and many other signs of the monkeys that reveal their super human native to the local community of Duasidan

fields.name: Monkey
fields.caption: There had had in historical times a festival in honor of the monkeys. This has however, died down due to modernity in religion and the death of the key people who had interest in the ritual performance of the monkey.

fields.name: Caretaker
fields.caption: The caretaker slicing some pawpawa fruit for the monkeys

fields.name: Monkey
fields.caption: The monkeys are locally powerful symbols, an physical expressing of life growth and vigor in the communities. They symbolize the status of the community at a particular point in time, the future and any mishap or success that may come on their way. For instance, the â€˜Cryingâ€™ of the monkeys continuous symbolizes trouble coming into the community. Captions from www.greenshepherdghana.org/

fields.name: Duasidan Monkeys
fields.caption: The new monkey sanctuary discovered at Duasidan in the Dormaa District of the Brong-Ahafo Region is over 120 years old and the sacred grove brings to two, the number of such sanctuaries in the region. The other one is at Buabeng-Fiema in the Nkoranza district.

fields.name: Xylophone
fields.caption: The gyil, an ancient xylophone, is the national instrument of the Dagara and Lobi nations of Ghana, Burkina Faso and Ivory Coast. The instrument is made with 14 wooden keys of an African hardwood called liga attached to a wooden frame, below which hang calabash gourds. Spider web silk covers small holes in the gourds to produce a buzzing sound, and antelope sinew and leather are used for the fastenings.

fields.name: Wardance
fields.caption: Wardances: a different rhythm is used during the historic wardance. For this occasion men are dressed in a traditional smock with a colourful cap and holding bows and arrows with quivers as a symbol of bravery.(SWOPA: Sirigu women organisation of pottery and art).

fields.name: Swopa
fields.caption: The village is well known for its traditional architecture, pottery and wall designing. Since 1997, more than 150 women of Sirigu have formed an organization for pottery and art (SWOPA: Sirigu women organisation of pottery and art).

fields.name: Cocoa Tree
fields.caption: The cocoa plants are low trees of the genus Theobroma cacao L., with fruit pods 20-30cm long (right), which are yellow or red in colour when mature. They contain a mildly sweet white pulp and many flat seeds, oil from which is used in cosmetics and perfume. The pulp is the source of chocolate and cocoa butter. There are 22 varieties of cocoa, categorized by the colour and shape of pods and their chemical makeup.

fields.name: Cocoa seedlings
fields.caption: Tetteh Quashie bears the sole credit as the Amelonado Cocoa plantain in the country.  The original nursery is now part of the Aburi Botanical Gardens.

fields.name: Tetteh Quarshie's Cocoa Farm
fields.caption: This was the first cocoa farm established in the country. The cocoa seeds are believed to have been brought from Fernando Po Island by Tetteh Quarshie, who set up the farm at Mampong-Akwapim in 1879. The farm was replanted in 1960, but 3 of the original trees still remain to this day.

fields.name: The First Cocoa Tree
fields.caption: One of the 3 remaining original trees in the farm.

fields.name: Cocoa Pod
fields.caption: It's not true that Tetteh Quarshie swallowed some cocoa seeds in a way of smuggling it. He actually hid 11 cocoa pods in his tools box and smuggled it to Ghana, 5 of which didn't do well at his hometown Teshie, because of weather conditions so he relocated to Mampong where he had his first farm in 1879.

fields.name: Tetteh Quarshie's Sandals
fields.caption: Slipper of a type used by Tetteh Quarshie. From this simple beginning, Ghana was destined to become the world's largest supplier of cocoa beans from 1910 until 1980. This Farm is at Mampong, less than an hour's drive from Accra.

fields.name: Tetteh Quarshie Cocoa Farm
fields.caption:
Pioneer of Ghana Cocoa Industry. Born 1842 parents of Ga origin was a blacksmith by
Profession visited Fernandopo in 1870. Brought cocoa pods on his return in 1876.Raised a farm At Mampong-Akwapim after three years efforts in 1879 died on 22nd  dec 1892. He was 50years.

fields.name: Mampong Waterfalls
fields.caption: After an hour's drive from Accra to Mampong-Akwapim, this waterfalls is some 40 minutes walk from the Tetteh Quarshie Cocoa Farm, through the rocky forest of Mampong.The surroundings of Mampong falls provide visitors with wonderful peaceful scenery that refreshes the mind.

fields.name: University Botanical Gardens
fields.caption: The big compound is adequate for children to play and have fun.

fields.name: University Botanical Gardens
fields.caption: The big compound is adequate for children to play and have fun.

fields.name: Banku and Chicken soup
fields.caption: Banku is one of the many staple foods in Ghana. Although it is said to have originated from the Volta Region by the Ewes, it is enjoyed by different tribes in Ghana. Ingredients: Fermented corn/cassava dough mixed proportionally and cooked in hot water into a smooth whitish consistent paste. Served with soup, stew or a pepper sauce with fish.

fields.name: Vegetation
fields.caption: Adaklu village and the surrounding land.

fields.name: Adaklu Mountain
fields.caption: Adaklu Mountain

fields.name: Hiking
fields.caption: Apart from the hike, there are also various other forms of entertainment including drumming and dance performances, bike tours to nearby villages, the sacred bats of Avanyaviwofe, and numerous other less taxing local tours.

fields.name: Communities and Lands
fields.caption: Atop Adaklu Mountain is a spectacular view of the surrounding communities and lands.

fields.name: Tourist
fields.caption: A Tour guide right up to the topmost part of Adaklu Mountain leads this challenging mountain Hike. It is located 12kms from Ho. You will encounter colourful birds, butterflies, monkeys and the natural surroundings whilst climbing. Camping is allowed on the mountaintop.

fields.name: Communities and Lands
fields.caption: At the top is a stunning view of three Adaklu villages and the surrounding land.

fields.name: Adaklu Mountain
fields.caption: The name Adaklu comes from the myth of the historic Ewe migration from Notse, Togo. The first settlers arrived to present-day Adaklu some four or five centuries ago and had brought along a cow. Once they arrived to their new home they prepared a feast, however one cow was insuffiecient and could not feed everyone. They solved this problem by sharing the broth among all the people. Adaklu literally means to share what you have cooked with everyone small-small, or klu-klu. â€œTendenâ€? is the local name for Adaklu Mountain which is praised as a traditional God.

fields.name: Climbing
fields.caption: Adaklu Mountain is the tallest free-standing mountain in Ghana. Local tour guides lead travelers on hikes to the pinnacle, which can take from two to three hours. There is a village halfway to the top that can provide a nice resting place with the best of coconuts, bananas, and hospitality.

fields.name: Adaklu Mountain
fields.caption: Adaklu Mountain is located in the Volta region of Ghana, West Africa. Several communities surround the mountain and it's the tallest free-standing mountain in Ghana. Photography by Elorm Beenie Kodzo of Ho,+233 27 125 44 80

fields.name: Bojo Beach
fields.caption: Chillaxin at Bojo Beach

fields.name: Bojo Beach
fields.caption: The Bojo White Sand Beach is the latest addition to the beach party situation arising along Ghana's 540Km pristine beach line. Situated next to the Densu delta Ramsar site and along the Atlantic Ocean, in its uniqueness and lovely blend of Caribbean and Ghanaian cultural architecture is the inviting Bojo beach.

fields.name: Bojo Beach
fields.caption: The beauty and uniqueness of Bojo beach stem from strategic location, concept, architecture and the serene environment.

fields.name: Bojo Beach
fields.caption: The facilities available for the beach goers come on a tall list that will keep you coming back at the least opportunity to have more of the excitement.

fields.name: Volley Ball
fields.caption: When you get there, get into interaction with the village folk if you want to experience authentic Ghanaian hospitality. There is nothing like playing around the beach with the village children who are always around.

fields.name: Bojo Beach
fields.caption: The beach area is another kind of island situated between the canal and the sea right on a stretch of sand bar. The sand bar has so much to offer that will surprise you. To get to the sand bar, you will have to cruise either by the Bojo Cruiser or a canoe over one of the Densu distributaries.

fields.name: Volley Ball
fields.caption: The most remarkable experiences come from the cuisine, wide range of assorted and local beverages. For an eventful day, you can take to swimming, water cruising, fishing, and volleyball, sand bathing, oyster trapping and more. Afraid? Wait a minute; there are lifeguards ready to rescue you. The lovely and lively youthful employees are a delight to interact with; their infectious smiles are never to be forgotten.

fields.name: Bojo Beach
fields.caption: The white sand beach is very clean so it is not surprising that most patrons prefer to hang around there.To get here,drive pass MacCathy Hill and pass Weija junction, then you start looking out for the old police barrier just ahead, on your left-hand side of the barrier is the Apalku or Kokrobite junction.Keep driving and within 5 minutes, you will drive through the Apalku village, start looking out for the imposing yellow Bojo Beach sign post from here that directs you to the left, you toss onto the dusty road and within seconds you will say voila! To Bojo. There is so much car parking space and excellent security at the car park.

fields.name: Bojo Beach
fields.caption: Its climate and serenity makes it an ideal place for the stressed that wants relief, the writer who wants solitary, the thinker for reflections and the one looking for beach sports. For those looking for a place to relax and plan the week, it is Bojo beach and nowhere else.

fields.name: The Chorkor oven
fields.caption: In Ghana, smoking is the most widely practised method of preserving, processing and storing fish. Practically all fish species available in the country can be smoked, and it has been estimated that between 70 and 80 percent of the domestic marine and freshwater fish catch is consumed in the smoked form. Fish smoking is also the most common economic activity for women living in the coastal towns and villages, as well as along the Volta Lake and rivers in fishing communities.

fields.caption: Farmers from a nearby village watch on as these amazing flying machines go through their paces.

fields.name: Building Aircraft
fields.caption: WAASPS is building aircraft to order for use in West Africa by pilots who have learned to fly from scratch, with us here in Ghana.

fields.name: WAASPS Aviation for Development
fields.caption: Not only does WAASPS offer flight training and air experience flights training and air experience flights, it also builds, maintains and operates tube-and-cloth and all-metal 2 seater aircraft in the sub-500kg category (Ultralight), and is developing a centre for build and support of the 4-seater Zenith CH801 STOL bush plane!

fields.name: Aircraft
fields.caption: Whether you are a young aspirant, a youthful enthusiast, a business man or woman who desires better communication solutions and travel options, seeking to learn a new skill, or a mature person seeking a lifelong desire to learn to fly and own your own aircraft, WAASPS has a solution for you!

fields.name: Aerial view
fields.caption: wow! an amazing view from the aircraft. To satisfy your curiosity and find out more simply contact WAASPS, they will help you aim higher. Call +233 28 5075254 / +233 28 5018028 website: www.waasps.com, e-mail: ep@waasps.com

fields.name: Island
fields.caption: Kpong Airfield is open every weekend, so that you can come along and watch the flight school in action. Every second Sunday of the month is 'Family Day' at Kpong Airfield, with a BBQ, games and the opportunity to meet with aviation-minded people of all ages in a friendly and refreshing environment. Allow about 70 minutes from Accra, and enjoy the drive out to discover some of the most beautiful countryside in the world.

fields.name: WAASPS Aviation for Development
fields.caption: Ghana is home to West Africa's premiere light aviation centre at Kpong Airfield in the Eastern Region, just 50km north of Tema and 30km south of Akosombo. Kpong Field is a private airfield, home to WAASPS, West Africa's leading light aviation specialists. Drive out to discover some of the most beautiful countryside in the world. Call +233 28 5075254 / +233 28 5018028 website: www.waasps.com, e-mail: ep@waasps.com

fields.name: Cyborg The Welder
fields.caption: Cyborg as he is popularly known at La, was born Benjamin Lartey and he's by far the best welder in Ghana. He has put in about months of work, including an engine rebuild which he prefers to put infront of the car rather than the back as it is with VW Beetle. He also welds and moulds car parts which are very difficult to find on the market. His workshop is located at La near the Mawuli restaurant. Call now +233 21 764888.

fields.name: The Cyborg Beetle Stretch

fields.name: Atimpoku
fields.caption:
Atimpoku is a town located along the Volta River in the Eastern Region of Ghana, and the capital of Asuogyaman District.
The town is the site of the Adomi Bridge, Ghana's largest suspension bridge, and is the largest major town to the Akosombo Dam, a hydroelectric facility which supplies the majority of Ghana's power needs. Here market women sell Abolo, one-man-thousand etc. to travellers and tourist.

fields.name: End Hunger Walk 2009
fields.caption: The walk is to remind the world, and ourselves, that in spite of the crises so severe and unprecedented that they have rocked the strongest, richest countries to their very foundation - in Ghana, the children are eating, children are learning, children are growing. Indeed, recent surveys show that the numbers of malnourished children living within these borders are coming down. There is progress and there are successes and they have been hard-won. They must be recognized.

fields.name: End Hunger Walk 2009
fields.caption: On Sunday June 7, 2009, Ghanaians joined the fight against hunger with a walk from the Golden Tulip Hotel to the Accra Mall. In countries all over the world, men, women and children are joining the fight against hunger, walking for a future where no child goes to bed hungry. The 'Walk' is organised every year by the World Food Programme (WFP) UN. Make it a date next year.

fields.name: Infra Red Sauna and a Jacuzzi bath
fields.caption: SPA is an abbreviation for the Latin phrase Sanus Per Aqua which means â€œHealth Through waterâ€?. A SPA is a centre for scientific relaxation and rejuvenation which helps to promote wellness and better health conditions. Basically it is a water treatment process

fields.name: Back, Shoulder, Neck Massage
fields.caption: Whether your idea of SPA means a long soak in the bath, visiting a day SPA or escaping to a luxury spa destination, Villa Cisneros Resort is your source for the best in healthy living and renewal.

fields.name: Swimming Pool
fields.caption: Enjoy having fun cruising by speedboat, traditional dug out canoe, BSI luxury boat or a 250 seater liner; swim in our semi-olympic size pool, lawn and table tennis and a wide variety of indoor games all at your disposal. You could also go biking , sports , fishing or bird watching. It is our pleasure to provide leisure. Come to us for a perfectly relaxing vacation

fields.name: Villa Cisneros Resort Sogakope
fields.caption:
Looking for one of the most beautiful riural settings Ghana can boast of? We have it, Located at the eastern bank of the Volta, Ghana's longest river, about 14 kilometres from the sea, on a 20 hectre estate at Sogakope in the Volta Region.... You'll find Villa Cisneros.The Gateway to Ghana's Rural Beauty. Lying midway between two West African Cities of Accra (Ghana) and Lome (Togo), it is within an hour's drive on asphalted road from each city.
Tel: +233 249795098, +233 277850326 or +233 244330624
cisnerosvilla2@yahoo.com www.villacisnerosresort.com

fields.name: Holy Trinity Spa and Health Farm (Sogakope)
fields.caption:
The Holy Trinity Spa and Health Farm at Sogakope is the First Spa & Health Farm in Ghana and second in Africa (outside South Africa. It is a destination SPA, Medical Spa, Rehab & Hospital Spa & Wellness Centre Spa. It has Doctors, Sports therapist, dietician, clinical psychologist, pastors, herbal practitioners. This Ultimate honeymoon destination is one and a half hours drive from Accra.  Call: 
+233 244 318298 , +233 244 311160 , +233 091 91334  email: info@htmcspa.com , website: www.htmcspa.com

fields.name: Boti Falls
fields.caption: The Fall flows from river ponpon which starts at Ahenkwa-Amalakpo and flows through various towns before reaching the town of Boti Langmase where it turns into the waterfalls.

fields.name: Afternoon Jam
fields.caption: Boti Waterfall is a sacred site and is home to a famous festival every July. It is good places for a picnic lunch so bring the Papaye Lodge Ice Box.

fields.name: Afternoon Jam
fields.caption: Boti Waterfall is a sacred site and is home to a famous festival every July. It is good places for a picnic lunch so bring the Papaye Lodge Ice Box.

fields.name: Boti Falls
fields.caption: Boti Falls is a 30m high waterfall within the Boti Forest Reserve about 30 minutes east of Koforidua. A small hike down some stone steps takes you to the waterfall with a pool at the base, which is safe for swimming. Guided walks of the forest and some caves can be arranged.

fields.name: Boti Falls
fields.caption: The Boti Fall is found in the forest reserve at a town known as Huhunya located in the Eastern Region of Ghana which is about 17km North-East of Koforidua, the capital of the region. Boti falls is actually made up of two waterfalls. According to the local people the big one is the male and the smaller one, a female. When the two merge, it is said that they are mating.The merging forms a rainbow. Within the vicinity of the falls are summer huts and other visitor facilities.

fields.name: My Photo Story
fields.caption: Now this is how I roll, a novel and some peace and quiet.  Occasionally chocolates but I can manage without it today.  This book keeps getting more interesting as I read.

fields.name: Three Headed Palm Tree
fields.caption: The three-headed palm tree has a huge stem base and from this singular stem base are three separate stems growing into the sky. The diameter of the base is about 126cm and the three stems have a diameter of about 70cm each. The height of the trees or three headed tree is about 3.2 m. It has huge lushly green leaves like any other palm tree.

fields.name: Umbrella Rock
fields.caption: Umbrella Rock

fields.name: Umbrella Rock
fields.caption:
The Umbrella Rock is about thirty minutes walk in the forest from Boti falls. The umbrella Rock is sited on a high land and thus, making it possible to watch nature hundreds of miles away into the green.
The Umbrella Rock is referred to as Akatamann, which simply means Umbrella in the Akan dialect.

fields.name: On top of Mount  Afadjato
fields.caption: Mount Afadjato is the highest mountain in Ghana, at an altitude of 880 m (2900ft). The mountain is located in the Agumatsa Range near the villages of Liati Wote and Gbledi, at the border with Togo.Last weekend members of the Calvary Methodist Youth Council made a trip to the Volta region and these are pictures of the places they toured.

fields.name: Akaa waterfalls
fields.caption: Just like Boti waterfalls, Akaa waterfalls is seasonal and it's best seen in June through to August.

fields.name: Rocks
fields.caption: The rock formation from the entrance of the falls to the falls itself is very unique and spectacular that a visitor to this fall cannot help admiring. The beauty of this rock formation is even more pronounced during dry seasons when water is not flowing through the rocks. This means that whether one visits the Akaa Falls in the wet or dry season, there are some very spectacular and interesting features to watch or admire. The most striking feature of this falls is its cascading nature.

fields.name: Akaa waterfalls
fields.caption: This Waterfall is located near the Akyeremateng village in the Akuapem North District about 2km away from Boti waterfalls. It takes sources from the Boti river, the very river from which the Boti Falls takes its source. It flows for most parts of the year just as the Boti Falls.

fields.name: Winneba (a historic fishing Town)
fields.caption: Winneba was founded by Osimpam Bondzie Abe 1 who had established a settlement there by 1400 AD. During the colonial era, Winneba served as a port town between Europe and the-then Gold Coast.

fields.name: Winneba (a historic fishing Town)
fields.caption: The town has a rich musical tradition and currently boasts of one of the leading musical groups in the country. The University of Education, Winneba is one of the leading educational institutions in Ghana. Until 1966 it was the Kwame Nkrumah Insititute of Ideology

fields.name: Fisherman
fields.caption: The main industries of Winneba are fishing and pottery. It is known for the Aboakyer deer-hunting festival of the Effutu people and its New Year fancy dress carnival. Winneba was founded by Osimpam Bondzie Abe 1 who had established a settlement there by 1400 AD. During the colonial era, Winneba served as a port town between Europe and the-then Gold Coast

fields.name: Winneba (a historic fishing Town)
fields.caption: Winneba, traditionally known as Simpa, is an historic fishing town in Ghana, lying on the south coast, 35 miles west of Accra and 90 miles east of Cape Coast. The population was recorded as 40,017 in a census in 2000. Its inhabitants are known as Simpafo or Effutufo. It is the capital of the Awutu/Effutu/Senya District in Central Region.

fields.name: Transportation in
fields.caption: Traders come from mainly the Afram plains and villages near by to sell and transportation is usually by boat.

fields.name: Harbin Entertainment Centre
fields.caption: Bowling is an anaerobic type of physical exercise, similar to walking with free weights. Bowling helps in burning calories and works muscle groups not usually exercised. The flexing and stretching in bowling works tendons, joints, ligaments, and muscles in the arms and promotes weight loss. Apart from the physical benefits it also has psycho-social benefits, strengthening friendships or creating new ones in groups.

fields.name: Bowler
fields.caption: Join the Bowling Club at Harbin Entertainment Centre on the Accra-tema road. The centre comes along with the first bowling game facilities in Ghana. It is fully equipped with the state-of-the-art equipment for this physical endurance and highly entertaining game in which heavy balls are rolled along a special track towards a group of wooden pins. It's located next door to the Next Door Beach Resort.

fields.name: Fort Prinzenstein
fields.caption: Fort Prinzenstein is a fort located at Keta, Ghana which was used in the slave trade. Prinzenstein is one of the few Forts that lie east of the Volta River. It was initially built by Danish traders in 1784 for defensive purposes in a war against the Anlo Ewe and to keep the area safe from other colonial powers. The fort was used as a dungeon for slaves awaiting transportation to the Caribbean. In 1850 the fort, along with the rest of the Danish Gold Coast was sold to Britain. The fort was used as a prison for a period before it was partially destroyed by the sea in 1980. The remains of the fort are now visited by tourists.

fields.name: Rocks
fields.caption: The goal of this project was to prevent chronic and periodic coastal erosion and flooding.

fields.name: Keta Sea Defence
fields.caption: Keta is a city in Volta Region, Ghana. It was an important trading post between the 14th and late 20th century via a port and fort built by the Dutch in 1784. Parts of the city were devastated by sea erosion between the 1960s and 1980s. There was a massive sea defence project few years ago, thus halting the disturbances of the sea.

fields.name: Lincoln University Football Squad of 1939 -1941
fields.caption:
Sitting: 2nd from Left Dr. Ebenezer Ako Adjei Standing: 1st from left Dr. Kwame Nkrumah

Nkrumah arrived in New York  towards the end of October 1934 and began his studies in Economics and Sociology at the Lincoln University  . In 1939 he obtained his B.A. degree with major in Economics and Sociology, and in 1942 qualified as Bachelor of Theology. He proceeded to the University  of Pennsylvania  in Philadelphia  where he obtained an M.Sc. degree in Education and an M.A. in Philosophy. While at the University of Pennsylvania  , he helped to set up the African Studies section there. He also helped to organize African students in America  and Canada  into an African Students Association of America and Canada  . At the first congress of the Association, he was , elected its president.

fields.name: W.E.B Du Bios and Kwame Nkrumah
fields.caption: Du Bois was invited to Ghana in 1961 by President Kwame Nkrumah to direct the Encyclopedia Africana, a government production, and a long-held dream of his. When, in 1963, he was refused a new U.S. passport, he and his wife, Shirley Graham Du Bois, became citizens of Ghana.

fields.name: Osagyefo Dr. Kwame Nkrumah
fields.caption:
Kwame Nkrumah (21 September 1909 - 27 April 1972), was an influential 20th century advocate of Pan-Africanism, and the leader of Ghana and its predecessor state, the Gold Coast, from 1952 to 1966.

In 1909, Kwame Nkrumah was born to Madam Nyaniba in Nkroful, Gold Coast.Nkrumah graduated from the prestigious Achimota School in Accra in 1930, studied at a Roman Catholic Seminary, and taught at a Catholic school in Axim. In 1935 he left Ghana for the United States, receiving a BA from Lincoln University, Pennsylvania in 1939, where he pledged the Mu Chapter of Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity, Inc., and received an STB (Bachelor of Sacred Theology) in 1942. Nkrumah earned a Master of Science in education from the University of Pennsylvania in 1942, and a Master of Arts in philosophy the following year. While lecturing in political science at Lincoln he was elected president of the African Students Organization of America and Canada. As an undergraduate at Lincoln he participated in at least one student theater production and published an essay on European government in Africa in the student newspaper,The Lincolnian.

fields.caption:

Address: PO Box EL 325, Elmina, Ghana, West Africa

fields.caption: Jamestown is one of the older areas of Accra and was heavily developed by the end of the 19th century. During the rapid growth of the city during the 20th century, Jamestown has become an area of a dense mixture of commercial and residential use.

fields.name: Elmina Bay resort
fields.caption:
Elmina Bay is a brand new hotel in the Cape Coast/Elmina area in the heart of the historic Central Region of Ghana. The resort, about 10 minutes drive from Elmina and 25 minutes from Cape Coast, is located on a beautiful, clean, palm-fringed beach, with cool and clean sea water, great for bathing.
Address: PO Box EL 325, Elmina, Ghana, West Africa

Email: elminabayresort@gmail.com

Phone: 054 161 4812 / 020 566 0670 / 028 524 0202 
Use country code 00233 from outside Ghana

fields.caption: Smoking is the major method of fish preservation on the Volta Lake. It is estimated that over 80 percent of the lake fish is smoked.

fields.name: Salted Fish in
fields.caption: Fish caught are mostly processed by the traditional methods of drying, salting and smoking. The processing method is chosen according to species and consumer preference. Most of the tilapia species caught are salted and sundried. Heterotis can be salted and sundried.

fields.name: River Bank in
fields.caption: This has become the easiest and cheapest way to get to the Torkor fish market but truth be told, it's time consuming as traders spend 5 to 6 hours on board before reaching the market.

fields.name: Kpando Torkor Fish Market in
fields.caption: Torkor is just some 8mins drive from Kpando and has one of the biggest fish markets in the Volta region.The boats here are very colourful and have funny names. Although, this form of transportation is slow, the fee is less compared to bus. Traders spend 3 cedis 50 pesewas together with their goods to get to the fish market. Traders here, mostly come from the Afram Plains in the eastern region of Ghana

fields.name: Hohoe Post Office
fields.caption:
That beauty contest, organized by the Department of Social
Welfare, was held at the Accra Community Centre on March 4, 1957, and 22-year old Miss Amekoafia, from Alavanyo in the erstwhile Trans VoltaTogoland now Volta Region, represented the Greater Accra Region.
Mr John Peter Amewu, the Hohoe District Chief Executive, said the
erection of the statuette was to immortalize the late Miss Ameakoafia
as an instrument of inspiration to the present generation especially
the youth.Mamaga Dewotornyo I, Queen of Gbi Traditional Area,
commended the district assembly for honouring Miss Amekoafia.

fields.name: Statuette of Miss Ghana 1957
fields.caption: The statuette of Miss Ghana 1957, Monica Amekoafia of blessed was unveiled at a brief ceremony as part of the country's Golden Jubilee celebration at Hohoe. The statuette, erected in front of the Hohoe Post Office, was in ivory and christened "Miss Monica Amekoafia" or "Miss Ghana." The statuette depicts Miss Amekoafia as a gem of Ghanaian beauty wearing a crown with a sash across her right shoulder with an inscription Miss Ghana.

fields.name: Gomoa Techiman
fields.caption: History has it that the people of Gomoa were part of the Fanti tribe which migrated from Techiman to Mankessim. They continued their journey southwards to Antseadze and finally found a stream and settled by it. They were the first to break the virgin forest and settled there.The Church of Pentecost is well noted for this, at funerals they come with loads of food stuff for the bereaved family and here at Gomoa Techiman, it's no different.

fields.name: Waakye
fields.caption: Waakye is a very popular Ghanaian food. It is often eaten as breakfast or launch, and sold by vendors on the streets of big and small cities alike in Ghana. The most basic form is made by boiling rice and beans together though variants include the addition of tomatoes, chillies, spices fish, prawns and assorted meats. This gentle prefers to eat his waakye from the big green leaf, says he's unable to break tradition!

fields.name: Bambara Beans and tatale
fields.caption: The classic way to serve tatale is with boiled bambara beans (aboboe) as in the photo above, or bean stew. Tatale and aboboe is a wonderful, elegantly simple party snack, especially pleasant when washed down with cold glasses of beer. It is also hearty enough for nonvegetarians to adore

fields.name: Bambara Beans Seller
fields.caption: Somewhere in Adabraka, a woman fries Tatale ( pounded rip plantain). This is served with boiled Bambara beans. Most people hate to prepare this at home because of the confusing ingredients that go into it. But trust me it's always worth the try, it's delicious!!!

fields.name: Food is ready!!!!!!
fields.caption: You are done with the soaking of your gari and can start enjoying the sweet lunch.

fields.name: Water time
fields.caption: Get a large bowl for soaking the gari. Make sure you have a lot cold water to soak the gari because cold water makes it taste good. With your gari in the bowl, pour cold water inside the bowl. You will see light substances showing up on the surface of the cold water. Pour those substances out of the bowl except getting rid of the gari. Afterward, make sure you pour some cold water inside the bowl to make sure the gari becomes all liquid. Don't let the gari solidify or else you aren't going to like your food. Gari is a similar to a nice cereal but it's eaten as lunch. But one can also go straight to the point without washing to get the impurities out of the gari.

fields.name: Mixing it up
fields.caption: Add sugar to the soaking and stir. Also, add a slight amount of salt to the gari. You cannot add too many tablespoons of sugar unless you aren't afraid of diabetes. Pour your peanuts inside the bowl containing the soaking of gari, sugar and water. Stir promptly. Add evaporated milk to the soaking containing gari, sugar, slight amount of salt, water and peanuts. Your choice of milk will be fine but Carnation Milk makes this food tastes so sweet. Add enough milk to the gari soaking.

fields.name: Soaking Gari
fields.caption: Soaking gari is done by people from all over the world. Gari is a nice food eating by people from Nigeria, Ghana, parts of South America, North America, Asia and Europe. When soaking gari, there are things you should do in order to the gari taste good. A.J is a radio presenter at Hitz FM in Accra and enjoys Gari Soakings not because it's easy to prepare but it tastes good to him. Here, he showed us how to prepare his favourite......... please read along you might pick some few points. Ingredients: (1)Gari (2) Evaporated milk or powdered milk (3)Sugar (4) A bit of salt (5) Peanuts and (6)Water

fields.name: Ave Maria Resort and Wellness Centre
fields.caption:
Ave Maria was built in the Early Fifties by Sir. W. Alcrow. The Resort is situated just meters from the Greenwich Meridian Rock.
Before the Queenâ€™s visit in 1962, the late President, Nkrumah ordered that a chalet and swimming pool should be built for the Queenâ€™s relaxation during her stay.


After the Queenâ€™s visit the late President Nkrumah visited regularly and the flag was hoisted each time, indicating his presence.
Today the chalet is a Guest room, called the Queenâ€™s Reading Room, guests get to overnight in this luxury and historical room, overlooking the pool.

fields.caption:
Sicut Miles Christi : (The Latin word for As a Soldier of Christ) is the motto of the school. 

In Bishop Augustine Herman's lifetime his personal motto was St Paul's words - SICUT MILES CHRISTI - which in English means AS A SOLDIER OF CHRIST. This has remained the motto of the College too.

Bishop Augustine Herman's wondrous deeds remain within the hearts and minds of the many faithful he converted to the Catholic faith in the Keta Diocese (now divided into two Dioceses, namely, Keta-Akatsi, Ho and Jasikan)

fields.name: Bishop Herman College--- www.bhobu.org
fields.caption:
Bishop Herman College was founded on February 28, 1952 at Kpando in the Volta Region of Ghana by the then Keta Diocese of the Catholic Church as a boy's Secondary Boarding school.

BIHECO as the school has come to be known, was named after Bishop Augustine Herman, a Frenchman who was Bishop of the Keta Diocese from 1923-1945. Bishop Herman's legendary exemplary Christian life and his love for education saw him setting up schools in most of the communities he succeeded in planting the Catholic faith. It came thus as no surprise that when the Keta Diocese wanted to establish an exemplary, par excellence secondary school to train young boys in the pursuit of spiritual and academic discipline they decided to name it after him.

fields.name: My Photo Story
fields.caption: I have spent so many years in London but one can never compare it with the months I've spent here in Ghana. I have relocated back to my roots and I'm so in love with this friendly and safe country. Indeed there is no place like home. Irrespective of my busy schedule at work, I make time out to chill. I love every minute here in Ghana, cruising from one end of this lovely nation to the other. Don't let me even start with those fabulous weekends filled with excitement from one joint to the other. Well if you want to know more about me, do continue reading my photo story. Hi everyone, I'm Nana Yaa.

Story by Albert Solomon

fields.name: At the Bar
fields.caption: Iâ€™m just trying to cool myself down in this heat with a cold beer.  Damn this is so refreshing!

fields.name: Swimming Pool
fields.caption: I usually prefer to crown a good drive with a wet swim, but Iâ€™ve got a business date so i'll pass for today.

fields.name: Performance report
fields.caption: A little chit-chat with the instructor, Iâ€™m trying to find out how I performed but I think his lying to me.

fields.name: Formula 1
fields.caption: Iâ€™m so happy that Iâ€™m still in one peace, and that Iâ€™ve had a successful drive

fields.name: After my final lap
fields.caption: Hmmmmmm! I hate this flag, you know why?  Itâ€™s my queue to stop racing.  Itâ€™s amazing how time flies when you are having fun.

fields.name: Race
fields.caption: Sadly Iâ€™m the one tagging behind by two laps.  Damn Iâ€™m so glad I didnâ€™t bet on this race.  I would have lost it terribly!

fields.name: Formula 1 LA RACE WAY
fields.caption: Formula One is very colourful, similar to the grand prix on tv.

fields.name: Crusin'
fields.caption: This is the part where I can say confidently that Iâ€™m a pro at this game. (4th lapïŠ)  See me in a chiller mode steering with one hand.

fields.name: Speed
fields.caption: Phew! What a relief, that curve was freaky.  I love speed but it must be reasonable.

fields.name: Turn
fields.caption: Some carts were simply made to beat the bends. I just pray I donâ€™t lose control in this curve.

fields.name: Think like a pro
fields.caption: I cannot be a pro without meditation before my race!

fields.name: Getting ready
fields.caption: You know how it goes, safety then fun.  I so cannot afford to break my neckâ€¦

fields.name: Formula 1 LA RACE WAY
fields.caption: When I want to destress, one of the best spots to choose from is Formula One. Itâ€™s situated behind the International Trade Fair at La.  For those of you who love the fast lane, this is the place for you.  I love go â€“cart cruising and guess what? I donâ€™t have to worry about traffic finesâ€¦

fields.name: my Photo Story 2
fields.caption: Life is a beautiful place but yet we tend to be oblivious most of the time.  The pressures of life can a times strangulate me but as you can see Iâ€™m still surviving.  Juggling work and studies is no joke but I guess making time out to chill keeps me sane and going.  For those of you, who may think Iâ€™m a smooth talker, well sorry to disappoint you.  Iâ€™m just finalizing my weekend plans.   Hello dear reader! Iâ€™m Albert Solomon, and this is my photo story.

fields.name: Hotel Accomodation
fields.caption:
Our five luxury chalets are found on a working citrus farm only 4 km away from the main gate of the Addo Elephant National Park. Although rain is prevalent in summer, we are a Malaria free area.
Whether you are looking for a luxurious holiday or fun-filled adventure, you are sure to have a memorable stay in our beautiful part of the country.

fields.name: Hotel Reception

fields.name: Private Car
fields.caption:
You need to have your own car here.
Walking is naturally prohibited in most areas of the park, and you wont get to see much sans a vehicle.
They do have tours but you really do need your own vehicle to get around and to view the animals properly.
There are many car hire companies in this area and their prices are competitive.

fields.name: Entrance Addo Elephant National Park
fields.caption: Several historic sites can be found in the area which date back as far as 1829. The most well known site is the Drift House, the Inn used by most people crossing the Addo drift from the old Cape Colony into the Hinterland.

fields.name: Addo Elephant National Park
fields.caption: Come to Addo and see the famous Addo elephants as well as mile after mile of verdant citrus trees, bearing fruit all winter and scenting the air with their blossoms in springtime.

fields.name: Addo Elephant National Park
fields.caption: Addo Elephant National Park is situated 72km by road from Port Elizabeth. Established in 1931 to save 11 Elephants on the brink of extinction, and now home to more than 350 of them, 280 Cape Buffalo, black Rhino, a range of Antelope species, as well as the rare flightless dung Beetle, Addo Elephant Elephant Park is a perfect destination for the adventurous outdoor and nature lover.

fields.name: Elephants
fields.caption: The park, the third largest in South Africa, offers a wide range of game viewing and outdoor activities, which include horse-back and horse-riding, guided walking, hiking and 4x4 trails and a picnic area for day visitors. Nothing could be better if you are a bush lover.

fields.name: Volley
fields.caption: If you are more the sportive type, there is a lot to do for you at Sajuna Beach Club. The river is the perfect place to practice all kinds of water sports. Sajuna Beach Club has her own rowboats and kayaks. A tourist boat is available for an interesting boat ride on the Volta river.There is also the possibility for beachvolleyball, soccer, basketball and many other sports.

fields.name: Tourist Boat
fields.caption: Sajuna Beach Club is located between Senchi and Atimpoku, on the Akosombo Road. We are opened every day from 9.00 AM until 6.00 PM. For party reservations you can call 020-8136825 or 024-8752158

fields.name: Boat ride

fields.name: Boat ride
fields.caption: Life jackets are provided by Sajuna Beach Club, free of charge. Professional captains on the motor boat and tourist boat will take you on the Volta River for an unforgettable boat trip.

fields.name: Adome Bridge
fields.caption: The Adomi Bridge is not at Akosombo. It is at Atimpoku and the Dam is at Akosombo. The end of the bridge is the village called Adome

fields.name: Boat ride
fields.caption:
Sajuna Beach Club is a great place to enjoy yourself.You can relax on the beautifully designed private beach, or have a barbecue on the white sand.
Sajuna Beach is located between Senchi and Atimpoku on the Akosombo road.We are openend every day from 9.00 AM until 6.00 PM.

fields.name: Accra Railway Station
fields.caption:
This is the main railway terminal in Accra. The intercity services are limited and the main route is from here to Sakumono and Nsawam. Railway services have not developed much beyond what was established during the colonial period.
Story by AMA ASAREBEA -----------------------
Edited by ADJOA KORANTENG------------------
Set Programming by NANA K. ANING------------------
Photography by KWAKU CHINTOH

fields.name: Ice-cream Vendor
fields.caption: Ice-cream Vendor

fields.name: Accra Railway Station
fields.caption: Accra Railway Station

fields.name: Accra Railway Station
fields.caption: Accra Railway Station

fields.name: Speed
fields.caption: Speed

fields.name: Traffic
fields.caption: I guess this picture virtually speaks for itself.  I would be stuck in this intolerable traffic jam if I had boarded a cab.  And worse would be inhaling fumes from the exhaust pipes of all these cars.  No wonder we are always getting sick.  This is just pure air pollution.  Phewwwww, thank God for the train.

fields.name: Ama, enjoying her Novel
fields.caption:
This novel is so interesting that I canâ€™t put this book down, itâ€™s totally addictive.  Iâ€™m feeling so relaxed because the seats in this train is so comfortable.  Well mokocharlie fans Iâ€™m about to reach my destination.  And this is the part where I say thank you for reading my photo story.
Choa!

fields.name: Ama buys an ice-cream to cool down
fields.caption: The one thing I enjoy about train rides are the stations.  At each stop you can get refreshments sold to you by hawkers.  You can get anything from ice-cream to cakes.  And as you cans see Iâ€™m getting myself some ice-cream to cool down.  Another interesting thing Iâ€™ve noticed is hawkers by the train stations donâ€™t harass you like the ones on the streets.  So I always get the opportunity to buy without any influence.

fields.name: Reading
fields.caption: Have you realized that itâ€™s virtually impossible to concentrate while reading in a noisy environment?  Well, try riding the train and you will see the difference.  You will surely have all the peace and serenity you need to enjoy a good novel

fields.name: Aloneness
fields.caption: Most people are not used to using the train down here, so itâ€™s mostly empty.  That can only mean one thing, a lonely ride.  However if youâ€™re like me and enjoy peace and quiet then you will love the ride.  Itâ€™s a perfect time and place to recollect on a dayâ€™s work.

fields.name: Stop
fields.caption: I guess this picture virtually speaks for itself.  I would be stuck in this intolerable traffic jam if I had boarded a cab.  And worse would be inhaling fumes from the exhaust pipes of all these cars.  No wonder we are always getting sick.  This is just pure air pollution.  Phewwwww, thank God for the train.

fields.name: My Photo Story 3 : Ama tells her story
fields.caption: A lady in subtle formal pink, this can only mean one thing, Iâ€™m a working class woman.  Hi guys my name is Ama.  Life in Ghana can really be frustrating especially when you work in a reputable company like me and cannot afford to be late.  How does one avert this absurd traffic congestion?  Well I will tell you how, by using the rail form of transportation.  I donâ€™t have time to be stuck in traffic for long hours as my family totally depends on me, since I do all the cooking at home.  And thatâ€™s why I love using the train; Iâ€™m totally guaranteed to reach home on time.  Keep on reading mokocharlie fans and I will show you how I beat the traffic everydayâ€¦

fields.name: My Photo Story: Aloneness
fields.caption: Most people are not used to using the train down here, so itâ€™s mostly empty.  That can only mean one thing, a lonely ride.  However if youâ€™re like me and enjoy peace and quiet then you will love the ride.  Itâ€™s a perfect time and place to recollect on a dayâ€™s work. This train runs Sakumono and Accra and this is how it's first class looks like. It has a well designed leather seat which is very comfortable to make one enjoy the ride.

fields.name: My Photo Story: Ama enters the train
fields.caption: One must be careful when climbing the steps to the train, it can be very tricky. On getting here early, one is able to find a good seat in the First class coach. The second class is usually crowded. And it's 60pesewas for First class and 50pesewas for the second class

fields.name: Old Folk
fields.caption: The old folks also prefer the train to Cabs and the Trotros just for the same reason...Traffic!

fields.name: My Photo Story: Aloneness
fields.caption: A train ride is so comfortable.  Unlike a car whereby you get tossed left and right each time the car turns.  I mean one can do some work in peace and comfort without having to worry about holding their laptops tight every second.  If you have a deadline you can be sure to complete it well before you reach work so you donâ€™t get fired.  Trains can sure be life savers!
