fields.name: Dungeon
fields.caption: The Dutch captured the fort in 1642 and traded slaves on a small scale until the abolition of the slave trade in 1807; the three dungeons â€“ for men, women and children â€“ only held about 25 slaves each, but by the time the Dutch sold the fort to the British the vultures had moved on to dead goats instead of dead slaves.

fields.name: Dungeon
fields.caption: The Dutch captured the fort in 1642 and traded slaves on a small scale until the abolition of the slave trade in 1807; the three dungeons â€“ for men, women and children â€“ only held about 25 slaves each, but by the time the Dutch sold the fort to the British the vultures had moved on to dead goats instead of dead slaves.

fields.name: Fort St Anthony,Axim town
fields.caption: The Portuguese constructed a rock-cut ditch some three metres deep to protect the landward side of the fort but this was later filled in during the 17th century. Inside the fort, a number of buildings of considerable size were raised to accommodate up to thirty officers.

fields.name: Tomb
fields.caption: The tomb of the First Portuguese  Governor who fell from his balcony and died, he was buried at the same place he fell.

fields.name: Fort St Anthony,Axim town
fields.caption: The fort was triangular in outline, in keeping with the contours of the promontory. Two major bastions were located on the northern and southern ends - the two corners of the wide end of the triangle. A curved battery linked them.

fields.name: Fort St Anthony,Axim town
fields.caption: Fort St Anthony,Axim town

fields.name: Fort St Anthony,Axim town
fields.caption: n ISIS, a small promontory close to the Ankobra mouth was chosen and a fort built to cover the entire promontory. It was named Santo Antonio and was the second Portuguese fort on the Gold Coast. The site chosen had several little inselbergs in the ocean close to the promontory.

fields.name: Fort St Anthony,Axim town
fields.caption: Following the establishment of their headquarters at Elmina, the Portuguese, in an effort to maintain their monopoly and exclude foreign ships from the gold markets, built a trade post in 1503 at Axim close to the mouth of the River Ankobra. Owing to attacks launched by the local people on the lodge, the trade post was abandoned.

fields.name: Fort St Anthony,Axim town
fields.caption: Fort St. Anthony fell to the Dutch four years after Elimina Castle â€“ in 1642. It remained an important focal point for the trade in slaves and gold through much of the Dutch period, until it was handed over to Great Britain in 1872.

fields.name: Light House
fields.caption: At low tide,tourist are able to walk from the shore to the Light house

fields.name: Cannon; Fort St Anthony,Axim town
fields.caption:
Fort St Anthony, the second oldest fort in Ghana after St George's in Elmina, is home to the biggest flock of vultures that I've ever seen.
The seaward view from Fort St Anthony reminds you that Axim had to defend itself against attack from the sea

fields.name: Fort St Anthony,Axim town
fields.caption: Axim has a prominent seaside fort, Saint Anthony, built by the Portuguese in 1515 and between 1642 and 1872 expanded and altered by the Dutch, who were in possession during that period. The fort, now property of the Ghanaian state is currently in the custody of the Ghana Museums van Monuments Board (GMMB) and is open to the public. Off-shore there are some picturesque islands, including one with a lighthouse.

Please join me this weekend. YOU'LL LOVE IT!!!!

fields.name: A typical Nzema Lady
fields.caption: Culturally, Axim forms part of the Nzema complex within the Akan culture. Residents speak the Evalue, Fante, and English languages. Most of the townsfolk profess Christianity, with many churches including Anglican, Catholic, Presbyterian, Pentecostal, and several newer sects. Axim has a small Islamic mosque, and numerous traditional fetish priests.

fields.name: photos from Axim Town
fields.caption: photos from Axim Town

fields.name: Fisherman
fields.caption: Every August, the major festival of Kundum takes place, coinciding with the best fishing-catch of the year; people come to Axim for the festivities and to fish and trade from several countries on the Guinea Coast.

fields.name: Axim Town
fields.caption: Axim is situated on the coast near the tropical rain forest of Ghanaâ€™s Western region, 270 kilometres from Accra, 70 kms from the Ivory Coast and 55 kms from the port of Takoradi. Axim is a town, district and kingdom on the coast of Ghana, in the Western Region to the west of Cape Three Points. Kwame Nkrumah, the first president of independent Ghana, was born in the small village of Nkroful, located just west of Axim, and lay buried there until the removal of his remains to Accra. In the 1930s, Nkrumah worked as headmaster of a Catholic school in Axim and led an intellectual circle there.

fields.name: Axim Town
fields.caption: An aerial view of Axim Town from Fort St. Anthony. The town is divided into two parts: Upper Axim and Lower Axim. The fort lies roughly on the division between the two parts, but closest to the centre of Upper Axim. Here, several large mansions of lumber-trading magnates and other businessmen remain from the British colonial period. Axim is ruled by two traditional omanhenes or chiefs and a political District Chief Executive of Nzema East.

fields.name: Axim Beach
fields.caption:
Axim Beach Hotel; The Hotel is situated directly on a sun-drenched tropical beach and offers guests total relaxation.
The hotel provides traditional Ghanaian style accommodation with modern facilities and genuine local hospitality. Come and enjoy our magnificent long sandy beach, delicious fresh food and the African way of life.

fields.name: Homowo Festival in Accra 2010
fields.caption: Homowo (hooting at hunger) is one of the colourful festivals celebrated by the people of Ga (Accra) Traditional Area. it is characterised by rituals such as the sprinkling of "Kpokpoi" (the festival dish) to the gods and ancestors for spiritual protection,procession of twins through the principal streets, traditional drumming and dancing and general merry-making. A month before the celebration, there is a ban of noise making. A climax of the festival is that from 12 noon to 6:00pm any woman, no matter the status, should accept a hug from a man on the festival street.

A climax of the festival is that from 12 noon to 6:00pm any woman, no matter the status, should accept a hug from a man on the festival street.

fields.name: Nkawkaw Town
fields.caption: Nkawkaw (meaning "the red, red") is an important town in the Kwahu West District of the Eastern Region of Ghana, with an estimated population in 2010 at 53,520.The town is inhabited by the Obomeng and Atibie ethnic groups.Nkawnkaw is situated on the road and former railway between Accra and Kumasi, and lies about halfway between these cities. It is also connected by road to Koforidua and Konongo. Nkawkaw is one of the major towns of the Kwahu Mountains. Historically it is not considered as a Kwahu town because its not on top of the mountain range. It is also home to most Tico Cars, here they are used as Taxis.

fields.caption: Take an adventurous ride on the different types boats available, and experience that unforgettable ride along the river. You would have the opportunity of seeing beautiful and blossoming islands close by. The villages are worth stopping over for an experience of indigeneous Ghanaian life, history and culture. Some of the villages you should stop by include; The Kwauno village, The Crocodile Village and The Dwarf Island.

fields.name: Restaurant
fields.caption:
The Restaurant offers a wide variety of fresh and appetizing Afro-European menu card with specialty on seafood. Special dishes like fish jambalaya, sole gretsiel,king prawns, tills redsnapper,tills special steaks should tried out. A sizeable variety of vegetarian are also available on menu. Hearty cold and hot starters, finger food, desserts are also available.
Special local Ghanaian dishes like fufu, banku, yam and palaver sauce,jollof rice etc are also available on menu and could be tried out. Special barbecue for groups and families can also be ordered and served on the beach around a bon fire.

fields.name: Wli Waterfalls
fields.caption: It is 20km from Hohoe, in the Wli Natural Reserve. This waterfall is becoming very popular in the West African sub-region. It is perennial, as water cascades throughout the year. It is located at the edge of the Agumatsa Wildlife Sanctuary, which has hundreds of fruit bats and a few monkeys and antelopes. This waterfall is becoming very popular in the West African sub-region.

fields.name: Making Palm oil
fields.caption: After the oil is squeezed out, the roughage is removed from the squeezer and dried.  After which it is sorted for palm kernels which is found inside the palm fruits.  Oil can also be extracted from the kernels also.  This is called palm kernel oil.  However I will end it here, how to extract oil from the kernels will be another dayâ€™s events.  Hope you enjoyed my photo story.  Cheers!

fields.name: Palm oil
fields.caption: I personally enjoyed this part.  This is the time for the strongest of men to display their power.  As simple as this may seem it requires brute power in order to turn the handle of the squeezer which extracts the oil as you can see it dripping.  This is done continuously until the oil ceases to come.  The oil is then distilled and after which you will see that it is red in colour.   This is so because of its high beta-carotene content.   Palm oil can be used for cooking and so many other things.  And there we are, our very own palm oil extracted from palm fruits!

fields.name: Palm oil
fields.caption: After the palm fruits have been pounded, they are placed into a metal squeezer which is man operated.  And I would like to congratulate these men because this part is the hardest.  They scoop out the mashed fruits while they are still hot like lava.

fields.name: Palm oil
fields.caption: After the fruits are well cooked, they pound it to get the fruit off the kernel and more hands are needed to complete this task.

fields.name: Palm oil
fields.caption: Here the ripe palm fruits are place in pots and cooked on an open flame for hours till the fruits are soft enough to be mashed.

fields.name: Palm oil
fields.caption:
Since the extraction of oil from palm trees is a long process, more hands are always necessary in order to accomplish the end product.  Here I witnessed so many people both men and woman sorting out the palm fruits and selecting the finest to be cooked.
As you can see the women have separated their ripe and unripe palm fruits which are now ready to be put in a pot on placed on an open fire and cooked.

fields.name: Making Palm oil
fields.caption: After the palm fruits have been removed from the pulp the fruits are sorted by hand to make sure that the finest are selected for processing.  In so doing they also remove the shrubs and weeds away from the fruits.  The ripe palm fruits produce more oil than the unripe ones.

fields.name: Making Palm oil
fields.caption: I watched this man with a cutlass cutting into the palm fruit bunches   in an attempt to release the palm fruits which will just fall loosely on the ground gradually.  It is a tedious job and one really needs to be careful else you can mutilate yourself.

fields.name: Making Palm oil
fields.caption: Palm trees are common in Africa, Latin America and parts of Asia.  And it is the highest oil producing tree known to man.   I went for a retreat and just couldnâ€™t help but share with you the process the inhabitants of this land go through in order to get oil.  I must say in as much as its exciting it is also loads of hard work!  And In this photo story I will take you through all the steps taken in order to achieve the end product, palm oilâ€¦ Hi, i'm Kwaku and this is my photo Story

fields.name: Olumo Rock - Nigeria
fields.caption: It is often helpful to enlist the services of a guide who possess vast knowledge of the history of the rock and the culture of the people. This makes for an interesting climb as every twist and turn will reveal a significant story making the trip a truly memorable one. On the way back down the rock, the sight of the Ogun river running like a silver chain amidst a forest of aged red corrugated roofs bordered by thick green forests which melt into the horizon is breathtaking.

fields.name: Olumo Rock - Nigeria
fields.caption: The ancient Itoku market where local artisans and traders enjoy to haggle over price just as much as the customers like to find a bargain ies just outside the Olumo rock premises and is a must-see. The market is the center of the indigenous Abeokuta industry of tie-and-dye, locally known as adire. Adire crafters, usually women, both old and young show off their designs in sheds alongside the roads. Behind these sheds are buildings where many of these crafters live and work and their parents before them. In places where the plaster has cracked off the walls, you may see traces of the mud bricks used in the original construction. The locals are very friendly and if asked, will often give tourists and visitors informal tours of the dyeing processes. Other popular items to watch out for include local beads, bracelets, sculptures and musical instruments like the sekere and talking drum.

fields.name: Olumo Rock - Nigeria
fields.caption: Tourists to Africa definitely need to consider putting Olumo rock on their travel plans. New renovations completed early 2006 upgraded the infrastructure of the site to include a new museum, restaurants, water fountain and an elevator that will provide even the climbing-challenged a wonderful view of the surrounding city.

fields.name: Olumo Rock - Nigeria
fields.caption: A trip to Olumo rock usually commences with a climb up the man-made stairs carved into the rock. While this sounds easy enough, it leaves many breathless and ready to take a break to rest on the benches under the trees growing from the rock and enjoy some clean breeze. The journey continues with climbs on irregularly sized rocks (or ladders which are now thankfully provided) through a narrow corridor that leads to the top of the rock. All along the way, catch sights of carvings in the rock, cowrie-studded statues and the ancient abode of the priestesses who live in huts on the rock. And yes, it is not uncommon to catch a sight of the very aged women who live there and mutter greetings or blessings as people make their way through.

fields.name: Olumo Rock - Nigeria
fields.caption: Abeokuta is just about an hours drive from the bustling metropolitan city of Lagos providing convenient access to an array of hotels, restaurants, clubs, casinos and various nightlife activities. Lagos is also home to the closest airport to Abeokuta, the Murtala Muhammed International Airport. Hotels in Abeokuta within minutes drive from the rock include Gateway Hotel and Olumo Guest House.

fields.name: Olumo Rock - Nigeria
fields.caption: Olumo rock, one of the most popular tourist destinations in Nigeria, West Africa, sits in the ancient city center of Abeokuta â€“ a name which means â€œUnder the rockâ€. Abeokuta was originally inhabited by the egba people who found refuge at the Olumo rock during inter-tribal wars in the 19th century. The rock provided sanctuary to the people as well as a vantage point to monitor the enemyâ€™s advance leading to eventual triumph in war. The town of Abeokuta eventually grew as these new settlers spread out from this location. (contact@olumorock.com)

fields.name: Tema Station
fields.caption:
From Accra, and of course also the other way, Tro-Tro's leave to these and other destinations:
Kaneshie Station: Cape Coast, Takoradi and other destinations to the west
Nkrumah Circle, or just named "Circle: Kumasi, Tamale and other far destinations to the north
Tema Station or also named "Accra": Tema, Aburi, and other local destinations
Tudu Station: Aflao, Ada, Hohoe, Akosombo and other destinations to the east and northeast
And then there are a few smaller places from where you can get Tro-Tro's.

fields.name: Tema Station
fields.caption: Tema Station

fields.name: Trotro
fields.caption: Every trip in a Tro-Tro is an adventure. The vehicles always are at least 20 years old, they are extremely uncomfortable, and very, very packed. An a small van they can fit at least 18 people.

fields.name: Tema Station
fields.caption: Every trip in a Tro-Tro is an adventure. But the Tro-Tro is the cheapest possible way of transportation, often it is the only way to get somewhere, and it is the perfect way to get to know the real Ghana and the real Ghanaians. There are no schedules of the departure times, if there are no passengers, it does not move. Most of the times though, it will leave within an hour after arriving at the station and in Accra normally even within 20 minutes.

fields.name: Tema Station
fields.caption: Tema Station is one of Ghana's main bus terminal from Accra to many part of the city.The most important way of transportation in Ghana is the Tro-Tro. A Tro-Tro is every vehicle that is bigger then a normal car and smaller then a bus. It can be anything: vans, pick-ups, small buses. Written by Pieter

fields.name: Halo Phenomenon
fields.caption: A rare celestial phenomenon occurred in the skies on Wednesday.A huge ring of a red-yellow-green band of halo circled the sun, much to the amazement of many.The phenomenon, referred to as the halo phenomenon, can be sighted around the world wherever the sun can be seen, meteorologists say. The appearance of the massive ring surprised many Ghanaians who have never witnessed it in their lifetime.Explaining the occurence, the chief forecaster at the Kotoka International Airport (KIA), Anthony Sewornuku, said refraction of light through crystals of water in the high clouds causes such a halo. Light from the sun is scattered when it hits the crystals to give such an effect. (Caption: myjoyonline)

fields.name: Halo Phenomenon
fields.caption: There are many types of ice halos. They are produced by the ice crystals in cirrus clouds high (5â€“10 km, or 3â€“6 miles) in the upper troposphere. The particular shape and orientation of the crystals is responsible for the type of halo observed. Light is reflected and refracted by the ice crystals and may split up into colors because of dispersion. The crystals behave like prisms and mirrors, refracting and reflecting sunlight between their faces, sending shafts of light in particular directions.

fields.name: Halo Phenomenon
fields.caption: A circular halo, often referred to as just a halo, is formed by the refraction of sunlight through cloud suspended ice crystals as opposed to raindrops or other liquid water suspended in the air. Sometimes only arc sections are visible as opposed to a full circle. Brighter sections can occur above, below, and lateral to the center (where the sun is visible). The lateral bright areas are referred to as "sun dogs," "parhelia" (plural), or mock suns because of their bright appearance and possible confusion with the actual location of the sun. The ones above and below the sun are the upper and lower tangent arcs, respectively

Cape Coast is the seat of the University of Cape Coast (UCC), Ghana's leading university in teaching and research. Cape Vars, as it is popularly called, lies on a hill overlooking the Atlantic Ocean. The city also boasts some of Ghana's finest secondary and technical schools:Wesley Girls' High School, St. Augustine College, Mfantsipim, Adisadel College (ADISCO), Aggrey Memorial Senior High School (AGGREY), Ghana National College (GHANACOLL), Holy Child Secondary,
Cape Coast Technical Institute (CAPETECH),
Cape Coast Polytechnic (C-POLY).

fields.name: Asafotufiam Festival
fields.caption: The people of Ada in the Greater Accra Region celebrate Asafotufiam. This festival is a warriors festival which starts on the last Thursday of July to the first Saturday of August. Asafotufiam celebrates the victories won by the warriors of Ada years ago. Furthermore the festival is meant to usher the people and the land into a new harvest season. There is a durbar put up by the chiefs and process in their beautiful and colorful palanquins followed by traditional military groups termed the Asafo Companies. After the drumming and dancing, libation is poured and prayers are said to ask for guidance and protection and thank the gods for the blessings in the previous year. Photography By Tsetse Quan

fields.caption: The Church of Saint George

fields.name: The Church of Saint George
fields.caption: The names of several places in the modern town and the general layout of the monolithic churches themselves are said to mimic names and patterns observed by Lalibela during the time he spent in Jerusalem and the Holy Land as a youth.

fields.name: The Church of Saint George
fields.caption: During the reign of Saint Gebre Mesqel Lalibela (a member of the Zagwe Dynasty, who ruled Ethiopia in the late 12th century and early 13th century) the current town of Lalibela was known as Roha. The saintly king was given this name due to a swarm of bees said to have surrounded him at his birth, which his mother took as a sign of his future reign as Emperor of Ethiopia.

fields.name: The Church of Saint George
fields.caption: The Church of Saint George

fields.name: The Church of Saint George
fields.caption: The Church of Saint George, Bete Medhane Alem, believed to be the largest monolithic church in the world.

fields.name: The Church of Saint George
fields.caption: The term primarily refers to the complex of eleven churches in Lalibela, Ethiopia believed to have been created in the 12th century, the most famous of which is the cross-shaped Church of St. George (Beta Giyorgis). Tradition credits its construction to King Lalibela, who was a devoted Christian. The 11 medieval monolithic churches of this 12th-century 'New Jerusalem' are situated in a mountainous region in the heart of Ethiopia near a traditional village.

fields.name: Albert Bosomtwe Sam Fishing Harbour
fields.caption: In 1999, a new fishing harbour â€“ the Albert Bosomtwe Sam Fishing Harbour â€“ was constructed at Sekondi, using a Government of Japan. The harbour is equipped with a cold store, an ice-making plant, offices, a berthing bay for inshore vessels, a jetty for canoes and a net drying area.

fields.name: Busia Beach Resort
fields.caption: Busua Beach Resort is located in Busua, close to Fort Metal Cross.It's the best place to watch the sunset, relax the mind and body. Busua Beach resort in Takoradi is by far the best beach I have been to in Ghana.The water here is pretty sedate and very inviting. The beach stretches for miles and there is little trash or crowds of people because it is quite remote.

fields.name: Underground Joint - Takoradi, Western Region
fields.caption: The Western Region is an integrated complex of beautiful safe beaches and African touch beach resorts; the largest collection of European trading forts Met used for the slave trade); the highest tropical jungles; numerous mines; old architectural styles and vivacious festivals. Takoradi, a harbor city is fast becoming a cruise Ship stopover.  "Underground" because it has no name...If you're in Takoradi now and looking for a place to hangu out, Call these numbers for directions you will be glad you did. This pub is in a secluded location and it's a MOKO exclusive... call the following numbers  for directions 0242809801

fields.name: Salenko Beach Resort
fields.caption: Immerse yourself in the tranquility of larger-than-life, seaside accommodations. Salenko Beach Resort is conveniently located on a secluded beach at the Accra High Street, near Ussher Fort. Here, guests and tourists alike can savour Ghanaian tradition and hospitality without compromising  on the state of the-art conveniences. Our friendly and dedicated team ensures you have a pleasant and wonderful stay. Be our guest, relax in a tropical setting and experience our warm, friendly service. Salenko Beach Resort is directly opposite Osekan Beach Resort

fields.name: Fort Good Hope
fields.caption: Fort Good Hope is situated in the little town of Senya Beraku in Ghana.In 1667 the Dutch established a lodge in Senya Beraku. In 1705-06, on invitation of the local Agona chief, they built a small stone triangular fort. They called it Fort de Goede Hoop, which translates to Fort Good Hope, for they hoped that trade in gold, ivory and slaves would boom. The fort was built on a promontory near a cove with a good landing beach.

fields.name: Elmina Bay resort
fields.caption:
Elmina Bay is a brand new hotel in the Cape Coast/Elmina area in the heart of the historic Central Region of Ghana. The resort, about 10 minutes drive from Elmina and 25 minutes from Cape Coast, is located on a beautiful, clean, palm-fringed beach, with cool and clean sea water, great for bathing.
Address: PO Box EL 325, Elmina, Ghana, West Africa

Email: elminabayresort@gmail.com

Phone: 054 161 4812 / 020 566 0670 / 028 524 0202 
Use country code 00233 from outside Ghana

fields.name: James Town
fields.caption: Jamestown is one of the older areas of Accra and was heavily developed by the end of the 19th century. During the rapid growth of the city during the 20th century, Jamestown has become an area of a dense mixture of commercial and residential use.

fields.name: Golden Tulip Kumasi City
fields.caption:
This remarkable hotel, the Golden Tulip Kumasi City is a first class African style business hotel set in extensive tropical gardens in the central business district of the Ashanti regional capital in Kumasi. Kumasi is the capital city of the Ashanti Region, a very important and historical centre.

This elegant hotel has 160 luxuriously furnished air-conditioned rooms with a variety of lodging accomodation like apartments, suites, executive, deluxe, superior and standard rooms. Our restaurant also offers a la carte style menu and buffets with international standards and local flavour. Golden Tulip Kumasi City - Rain Tree Street - 0000 - Kumasi - Ghana
Tel: Telephone: + 233 (0)32 20 83777 - Fax: (+233) 03220 83711 - Email: info@goldentulipkumasicity.com

fields.name: Lake Bosomtwe
fields.caption: This lake and its surrounding crater was created by a large meteorite strike that took place around 1.07 million years ago. The lake is around 25sq km, and up to 90m deep, while the crater it is within is larger, with crater walls rising to 600m and covering an area of 49sq km, 8.6km across at its widest and 8.1km at its narrowest, this is the largest natural fresh water body in Ghana, and is filled by rainwater. Lake Volta being artificially created by adding dams.

fields.name: Ostrich
fields.caption: The vegetation of Shai Hills is dry, coastal evergreen savannah and 40% of the park is made up of imposing hills covered with dry forest. Major wildlife to be seen include olive baboons in large numbers, green monkeys, kobs and bushbucks, as well as monitor lizards, pythons and snakes. Bird lovers will also find Senegal parrot, grey plantain eater, hornbill, red northern bishop and violet turaco. Other birds to be found in Shai Hills include Senegal cuckoo, stone partridge and francolin.

fields.name: Baboon
fields.caption: The vegetation of Shai Hills is dry, coastal evergreen savannah and 40% of the park is made up of imposing hills covered with dry forest. Major wildlife to be seen include olive baboons in large numbers, green monkeys, kobs and bushbucks, as well as monitor lizards, pythons and snakes. Bird lovers will also find Senegal parrot, grey plantain eater, hornbill, red northern bishop and violet turaco. Other birds to be found in Shai Hills include Senegal cuckoo, stone partridge and francolin.

fields.name: Baboon
fields.caption: The vegetation of Shai Hills is dry, coastal evergreen savannah and 40% of the park is made up of imposing hills covered with dry forest. Major wildlife to be seen include olive baboons in large numbers, green monkeys, kobs and bushbucks, as well as monitor lizards, pythons and snakes. Bird lovers will also find Senegal parrot, grey plantain eater, hornbill, red northern bishop and violet turaco. Other birds to be found in Shai Hills include Senegal cuckoo, stone partridge and francolin.

fields.name: Visitors
fields.caption: Shai Hills was home to the Shai people until 1873 when the British colonial army expelled them as they were alleged to be committing ritual murder.. Visitors to Shai Hills and those looking for adventure make it a point to visit to any or all of the three caves, Adwuku, Sayu and Hieweyu. The three caves with different profiles offer the visitor a good physical exercise, especially for those who scale the Adwuku cave to the top to view the vast Accra plains.

fields.name: Baboon
fields.caption: The vegetation of Shai Hills is dry, coastal evergreen savannah and 40% of the park is made up of imposing hills covered with dry forest. Major wildlife to be seen include olive baboons in large numbers, green monkeys, kobs and bushbucks, as well as monitor lizards, pythons and snakes. Bird lovers will also find Senegal parrot, grey plantain eater, hornbill, red northern bishop and violet turaco. Other birds to be found in Shai Hills include Senegal cuckoo, stone partridge and francolin.

fields.name: Hill
fields.caption:
Shai Hills Resource Reserve is only 51 square kilometres and is the wildlife park closest to Accra. It takes less than an hour to reach the park on the road to the Volta lake. The park is famous for the large bands of olive baboon that over-run the highway beside the park in the mornings and evenings. The Wildlife Division has plans to replace the fence around the park with support from the private sector so that it can be restocked with wildlife
Shai Hills has a varied package of wildlife, archaeological sites, carves and granite hills and is located in the Dangme West District of the Greater Accra Region. The distance to Accra is  about 50km.

fields.name: Cave
fields.caption: In September â€“ October, the local people celebrate the Manyam festival that brings the community to the parkâ€™s caves for the performance of ethnic rituals. Best time for visiting is October to May. Shai Hill has a resort hotel close to its northern gate. The park has an interpretation centre from where visitors launch their tour of the park.

fields.name: Central Market - Bantama, Kumasi
fields.caption: The Asante kingdom is made up of 33 traditional areas, and Bantama is one of the four traditional quarters of the Kumasi Traditional Council, the inner circle of the monarchy. Bantama traditional quarter holds a very important position in the Asante nation as one of only three stools, or thrones, succeeded through the male line in Asante. See photos of the central market at Bantama, Kumasi.

fields.name: Nzulezu - stilt village
fields.caption: The village of Nzulezo is located near the village of Beyin, roughly 90 kilometers west of Takoradi, in the Jomoro District of the Western Region of Ghana. Nzulezo overlooks the Lake Tadane, and is entirely made up of stilts and platforms.

If there is one thing I have learnt as a young sports man, its hard work and dedication. Hence I make it a point to train at least 3hrs a day, starting from 4 to 7 pmâ€¦ however itâ€™s after Iâ€™m done with my homework.

fields.name: Prayer before training
fields.caption:
I have learnt to acknowledge God in all i do, this is me, praying before i start training.

tying my bandage which is a necessary preparation for any fightâ€¦Too fast too furious!

fields.name: Young and talented

â€œThe bigger they are the harder they fallâ€, ever heard of that saying? It doesnâ€™t matter how tough you are, Iâ€™m always ready for a fight.

fields.name: La Cigale All in one wedding venue
fields.caption:
La Cigale is a All In One Venue, specialising in weddings, conferences, self-catering accommodation and corporate functions.

The improved wedding venue can now accommodate up to 120 guests. We offer a large variety of menus which can be tailor made referring to personal preferences and budgets.

fields.name: Judo in Ghana
fields.caption: Judo is a modern martial art, combat and Olympic sport created in Japan in 1882 by Jigoro Kano. Its most prominent feature is its competitive element, where the objective is to either throw or takedown an opponent to the ground or force an opponent to submit with a joint lock or a choke.The variety of skills acquired from Judo are transferred to many other sports. In particular, breakfalls can be used to prevent injuries in many contact sports such as rugby and other football codes.  Learn to Judo at the Accra sports stadium every Monday, Wednesday and Friday at 5:00pm.

fields.name: Kumasi Zoo
fields.caption: The Kumasi Zoo (Kumasi Zoological Garden) is a zoo located in the heart of Kumasi in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. The zoo occupies a 1.5-square-kilometre (370-acre) area between the Kejetia Bus Terminal, the old race course and the Kumasi Centre for National Culture.

fields.name: Camel
fields.caption: It has about 40 different species of animals, with individual animals numbering over 135. A notable feature is the thousands of bats that rest on trees in the zoo.

fields.name: Kumasi Zoo
fields.caption: The zoo was established in 1951 and officially opened in 1957 by the Asanteman Council to conserve nature and display indigenous wild animals of Ghana.

fields.name: Ducks
fields.caption: It has about 40 different species of animals, with individual animals numbering over 135. A notable feature is the thousands of bats that rest on trees in the zoo.

fields.name: Microflush Biofil Toilet
fields.caption: The Microflush Biofil Toilet is a unique sanitation innovation that provides an improved toilet (one that separates waste from human contact) while promoting hand washing, eliminating odor, and producing fertilizer.  The user uses the toilet much like a Western-style sitting toilet, flushes it by stepping on the lever, and finally washes his/her hands in the sink.

fields.name: Microflush Biofil Toilet
fields.caption: The sink then drains into the toilet bowl, filling it for the next user to use.  The unit is actually a combination of two technologies.  The first is the Microflush technology, developed by Dr. Stephen Mecca of Providence College.  This technology uses a trapdoor-esque bottom to the toilet bowl. The Microflush Biofil. Water from the sink fills the toilet bowl for the next user.

fields.name: Microflush Biofil Toilet
fields.caption: The Microflush Biofil Toilet is a unique sanitation innovation that provides an improved toilet (one that separates waste from human contact) while promoting hand washing, eliminating odor, and producing fertilizer.

fields.name: Microflush Biofil Toilet
fields.caption: When a lever is pressed, the trapdoor falls open, disposing of the waste into the Biofil tank, and then sealing to effectively prevent any odor from escaping.  The Biofil technology uses vermiculture (worms and microorganisms) in the septic tank to naturally decompose the waste.

fields.name: Microflush Biofil Toilet
fields.caption: When a lever is pressed, the trapdoor falls open, disposing of the waste into the Biofil tank, and then sealing to effectively prevent any odor from escaping.  The Biofil technology uses vermiculture (worms and microorganisms) in the septic tank to naturally decompose the waste.

fields.name: The Microflush Biofil Toilet
fields.caption: After about two years of use, the tank is usually full and is let to sit for two weeks.  Then, the contents are removed and can be used as a dry, natural, and pathogen-free fertilizer.  There is no waste to be disposed of, for the fertilizer can be sold to farmers for a profit. The composted fertilizer substrate harvested from the Microflush Biofilâ€™s tank
